sublinks.title: Rory McIlroy / World No1 charges up leaderboard but leaves it too late
sublinks.rawTitle: World No1 charges up leaderboard but leaves it too late

item.title: Rory McIlroy charges up US Open leaderboard but leaves it too late
item.trailText: The world No1, Rory McIlriy, shot a superb final-round 66 at Chambers Bay to give the US Open leaders a scare but it was not enough for the Northern Irishman
item.standFirst:
• World No1 shoots final-round 66 to end on level-par aggregate
• Terrific late effort cannot haul in leaders at Chambers Bay
item.body:
Rory McIlroy was still 16 years from being born the last time the final round of a US Open began with a four-way tie. And yet, somehow, the world No1 summoned the spirit of 1973 on Sunday at Chambers Bay.

Related: US Open 2015: final round – live! | Scott Murray

On that historic occasion Johnny Miller produced a 63 to upstage the quartet who had earlier been in pole position for the major. Here McIlroy embarked on a turbo-charged run which saw him reach the turn in 32 before holing birdies at the 10th – where he played one of the shots of the tournament from a fairway bunker to within 3ft of the hole – 12th and 13th. The third of those arrived via a 72ft putt from over the back of the putting surface.

Roars reverberated around the venue. McIlroy had confirmed an ability to produce these cataclysmic surges which no other player in this sport can replicate. From the 14th green Marc Warren, in the group in front of McIlroy and John Senden, stood back just to watch the four-time major winner’s drive. Even fellow professionals knew what was taking place.

Perhaps McIlroy was not even the one smiling most widely. The USGA and its executive director, Mike Davis, finally had a counter-argument against the wave of criticism this event has withstood. A finale featuring McIlroy in such imperious form, after all, is hardly the domain of a two-bit event. Some of the sniping towards Chambers Bay has been perfectly valid. The 115th US Open, though, reached its conclusion in nail-biting circumstances and with the game’s most prominent figures as the leading players.

The Northern Irishman’s wings were clipped with a bogey on the par-three 15th. The putting woe which had undermined his attempt to run away with this competition, never mind win it, returned. He failed to recover on the short 16th, missed a tiny putt for par on the penultimate hole and ultimately signed for 66 and an even-par 72-hole total.

This represented a magnificent, if belated, effort. The sense that the Open Championship, at the Old Course he so adores, cannot come quickly enough for McIlroy is unavoidable.

Earlier Chris Kirk had offered the most fierce critique of the USGA. The American, who opened his fourth round with a 10, was in no better mood by the time he took to the locker room. Kirk claimed the USGA should be “ashamed of what they did” to this tournament.

Billy Horschel stopped only narrowly short of implanting his putter into a green by way of exhibiting his frustration. The FedEx Cup holder shot 67 on Sunday but was still scathing in his assessment of four days in the Pacific north-west.

“I think a lot of players, and I’m one of them, have lost some respect for the USGA and this championship this year for the greens,” said Horschel.

“It sounds like the players are whining and complaining. Well, you’re playing for millions of dollars, you’re playing for the US Open championship. We’re not looking for perfect greens. We’re not looking for Memorial’s greens or even last week at TPC Southwind in Memphis, at the FedEx St Jude Classic. But we’re looking for something that’s very consistent. Every green is very consistent. And this week they’re not.”

Sergio García signed off with a 68 for three over in total. Justin Rose’s 71 was for plus five. Phil Mickelson had gone 71 holes without a double bogey before taking a fresh air swipe in rough at the last, causing precisely that. He kept his post-round comments to 49 words after a 73.

Lee Westwood was more expansive. The Englishman closed on nine over after an even-par 70. “It’s the kind of course I would like to come and play with my mates, with a cart and a few beers,” he said. “There are certain aspects to it that I don’t think are right for a US Open but I am thinking more from a fan’s point of view. It’s been a strange atmosphere out there because they can’t seem to get close to the action on some holes. I watched Phil Mickelson tee off on the 1st today and they are not going to see him again until his second shot on the 2nd hole.

“From a fan’s point of view it would have been an even harder walk than the players. It’s actually quite dangerous for them. I would be interested to see how active the First Aid tents have been this week. It’s treacherous out there.

“The greens being in poor condition is obviously disappointing. It’s the US Open, you want it in pristine condition but sometimes these things are out of your control.”

sublinks.title: US Open / Day driven to succeed by caddie after refusal to buckle
sublinks.rawTitle: Day driven to succeed by caddie after refusal to buckle

item.title: Jason Day draws on special relationship with caddie at US Open
item.trailText: Jason Day and his caddie Colin Swatton drew on a special relationship to complete their third round at Chambers Bay, but it took something extraordinary for the Australian to remain in contention at the US Open
item.standFirst:
• Australian used to adversity refused to give in to vertigo at Chambers Bay
• Colin Swatton believes Day’s third round has the makings of a blockbuster
item.body:
The relationship between Jason Day and Colin Swatton did not start promisingly. Their first encounter was something of a metaphor for the golfer’s troubled early life.

When Day was 12, his father Alvin died from stomach cancer. This proved the trigger for Day Jr to go spectacularly off the rails; drinking, street fighting, sleeping in gutters were a standard part of his sad routine.

Day’s mother regarded extreme action as necessary. She borrowed money to place Jason in a boarding school, Kooralbyn, a golf-centric establishment in south-east Queensland. Adam Scott is another famous alumnus, as is the former Olympic sprinter Cathy Freeman.

This is where Swatton – Day’s caddie, lifetime coach, mentor but at that stage Kooralbyn golf instructor – came in. On the pair’s very first meeting, Swatton asked a group involving Day to take part in a short-game drill. As was his wont at the time, Day’s objection was vehement, in Foxtrot Oscar form; he wanted to play on the par-three course. He was left to do as he wished.

After a couple of hours the head-strong youngster re-appeared and apologised, a move which convinced Swatton of underlying decency beyond a tortured mind. An alliance had been formed. Within months Day’s peers were looking up to him; none could match his work ethic. Golf had become his addiction. When Swatton moved on to the Hills International College Day followed him. He was soon to become recognised as one of the best young amateur players in the world.

At Chambers Bay the 46-year-old Swatton looked on with as much surprise as anyone – albeit with more concern – as Day struggled with the effects of vertigo to challenge for the US Open. Regardless of the ultimate outcome, Day’s ability to battle adversity had been confirmed.

“I just encouraged him to be positive, trying to position the least amount of stress,” Swatton explained of his role. “It’s hard enough to play anyway, let alone trying to position him somewhere where he’s not stressing about the next shot. But I just tried give him encouragement, make sure he was hydrated, make sure he had enough food. Just be there.”

Day’s sense of doing the right thing arose once again at this event, when he issued a statement to say sorry for not completing full media duties at the end of round three. It was unnecessary, given his obvious health and energy issues.

Day has always been effusive about Swatton, labelling him as “family”. He added: “It feels like he is my right arm. I couldn’t play golf without him.” Before that third round, a matter of hours after Day had collapsed on the final hole of his second, Swatton issued a firm message.

“I said, ‘You’ve got the heart of a lion. You’re going to show the world today you’re going to be the greatest you can be.’ And I said, ‘Let’s do it.’

“And he just put his head down and kept walking one foot in front of the other. It was pretty impressive. I kept feeding him water and giving him food, just giving him encouragement, just trying to get him through. I said to him, ‘They’re going to make a movie about that round.’ It was pretty impressive, it was up there with Tiger Woods playing with a broken leg at the US Open. It was very impressive.”

Even in supposedly stable times, and amid a rise to a high point of fourth in the world rankings, Day has never had things particularly easy. In 2013 eight members of his family were killed in the typhoon which hit the Philippines. Immediately afterwards Day not only turned out for Australia in the World Cup of golf but won both the individual and team events.

Before this year’s Masters Day revealed that he had feared having to retire from golf because of a thumb injury which ruined his 2014 season. Injuries have been a regular, troubling theme throughout his stop-start career.

“Over the last couple of years I’ve been fed up with being injured, fed up with sitting out and watching the guys play without me being there,” he said this week. “It’s been really frustrating and disappointing at the same time because I feel I have the potential to go out there and play well and win a lot. But with injuries it’s tough to do, especially at the highest level.”

Day hired a fitness expert to help with his development but Swatton has never been, and surely never will be, replaced. Theirs is one of golf’s most endearing partnerships.

cards.title: Tennis / Murray 'in better place than in 2013 for Wimbledon'
cards.rawTitle: Murray 'in better place than in 2013 for Wimbledon'

item.title: Andy Murray says he is in better place than when he won Wimbledon in 2013
item.trailText: The world No3 left Queen’s a champion for the fourth time and said he is better placed to win Wimbledon than he was when he won the title two years ago
item.standFirst:
• ‘I feel I have improved. Physically I’m in a better place’
• World No3 looks ahead to Wimbledon after Queen’s victory
item.body:
Andy Murray left Queen’s a smiling champion for the fourth time on Sunday and believes he is better placed to win Wimbledon than he was when he beat Novak Djokovic in the final two years ago.

“You just have to improve, otherwise I wouldn’t still be in the same position,” he said after beating Kevin Anderson 6-3, 6-4 in the final of the Aegon Championships – two hours after completing a 6-3, 7-6 victory over Viktor Troicki on the same Centre Court in their interrupted semi-final.

“I was ranked [No2 in the world] around that time [when he beat Djokovic at Wimbledon in 2013] and I’m still there now [at No3]. Sport and life … everything moves on. If you don’t get better, there are people who will take your spot.

“I feel I have improved. Physically I’m definitely in a better place than I was then, when I was having problems with my back – not so much on the grass but on the other surfaces.

Related: Andy Murray beats Kevin Anderson to win Queen’s title for fourth time

“I feel I’m using my variety very well now, something that maybe I wasn’t the past couple of years. [I have] more experience, more matches. There are a few things I’m doing a little bit better.”

Murray joins four other four-time Queen’s winners in John McEnroe, Boris Becker, Lleyton Hewitt and Andy Roddick. But, when reminded he went on to win Wimbledon after winning here in 2013, he said there was no direct connection.

“That means nothing, really. There are no guarantees that winning here gives you a Wimbledon title. I need to go out there and earn it. I need to train well the next five, six days.

“It’s great preparation, a great start to my preparation on the grass. It gives me that little bit of confidence going in there. But it’s a long way to go before Wimbledon even starts and then all sorts of things can happen during slams.”

Murray paid tribute to his coach of one year, Amélie Mauresmo, augmented lately by the input of Jonas Bjorkman, for the adjustments to his game that have allowed him to play his best tennis in two years, on grass and clay.

She arrives in London on Monday evening, having left Bjorkman to oversee Murray’s training at Queen’s, and will hand on to him again after Wimbledon, as she is expecting her first child in August.

“Obviously I’m not going to stay undefeated with him forever,” Murray said of his winning sequence of nine matches and two tournaments. “But I also have to give a lot of credit to Amélie. The things I have worked on with her, like using my variety, I have spoken about a lot. Hopefully a culmination of the two of them will give me more success. I have spoken to Amélie a couple of times on the phone and we message every day. It’s been a good start.”

He added: “I won’t train tomorrow, and will probably be at Wimbledon on Tuesday. I’m doing something for Tim Henman’s foundation at Roehampton on Tuesday. The rest of the week I will be at Wimbledon training.”

It is looking very much like business as usual for a player growing in confidence by the day.

sublinks.title: Report / Murray sees off Anderson to win fourth Queen's title
sublinks.rawTitle: Murray sees off Anderson to win fourth Queen's title

item.title: Andy Murray beats Kevin Anderson to win Queen’s title for fourth time
item.trailText: Andy Murray became a record-equalling four-time winner at Queen’s after outclassing Kevin Anderson to win 6-3. 6-4 in the final at Queen’s
item.standFirst:
• Murray beats South African 6-3, 6-4 in final of Aegon Championships
• Scot completed semi-final win over Viktor Troicki earlier on Sunday
item.body:
Andy Murray could hardly be fitter, happier or in better form a week before Wimbledon. He exuded calm and self-belief in winning his fourth Queen’s title on Sunday – and, given his natural diffidence, that encourages the growing perception that he will be standing opposite the defending champion, Novak Djokovic, on the final Sunday at the All England Club.

Whether or not the Scot can beat the Serb there again to win a second title to go with the trophy he lifted two years ago will be the subject of debate over the next few weeks – I think he can – but Murray believes so, and that matters more than the opinion of any expert. There is no discernible doubt in his eyes, just quiet determination born of the consistency he has shown in the intervening period.

On clay, too, he has been exceptional, unbeaten in 15 matches before Djokovic stopped him in the semi-final at Roland Garros this month. In that red run, Murray won his first two clay-court titles, contributing to Rafael Nadal’s woes in Madrid, and he has effortlessly taken his form on to his favourite surface over the past week.

Djokovic is the only player to beat Murray on any court in 30 completed tour matches since Borna Coric in Dubai in February (discounting David Goffin’s retirement walkover in Rome, and Murray’s two Davis Cup wins) – although the Serb has also prevailed in the two slams, the Australian and French Open, as well as the semi-final at Indian Wells and the final in Miami. So those setbacks against his nearest contemporary will have left their mark – one eased by marriage. Murray has lost only once since his wedding to Kim in April.

It is Djokovic whom Murray has always wanted to beat most – and he could hardly have greater incentive given the chasm of 6,300 points between the world No1 and the world No3. The 500 points Murray has garnered here – along with £273,000 – will have restored much of his confidence.

All of that is to do with his mind (and his bank account). His body and his tennis are pertinent too, and they are in fantastic shape. His natural caution, meanwhile, will direct him towards events in Halle on Sunday, where Roger Federer, 2,005 points ahead of him in the rankings and 15 majors to the good, beat Andreas Seppi 7-6, 6-4 to win another title on the German grass. Can the Swiss, without a slam in three years, sustain his form over seven best-of-five matches at Wimbledon? Another conundrum.

But it was not just that Murray joined John McEnroe, Boris Becker, Lleyton Hewitt and Andy Roddick as a four-times winner of the Queen’s title, but the sustained brilliance of his performance in subduing two excellent opponents in one day, Viktor Troicki in the morning and Kevin Anderson in the afternoon, that inspired the view among many good judges that he can win Wimbledon again. This was a two-part masterclass against players of vastly contrasting styles, separated by a little over two hours of rest, and completed in 124 minutes.

After resisting the robust challenge of Troicki in an hour to complete a 6-3, 7-6 victory in a semi-final held over from Saturday evening, the Scot was back at 2.25pm to deal with the monster serving of Anderson, who came to the final having put an astounding 96 aces past his four opponents.

Even Anderson’s fastest serve of the day – 138 miles an hour in the seventh game of the second set – did not put Murray out of his measured stride across grass as rich and slick as some of the watching patrons. After a little more than an hour, Murray served for the match. He sealed it with a superb away-swinging serve to the deuce corner and could barely contain his smile as Queen’s rose to greet him in a warm, extended chorus of applause. Tim Henman could hardly have made them happier.

The sheer variety of Murray’s shot-making under pressure brought unease to Anderson’s hitherto buoyant tennis. Murray lobbed him, dinked and chipped with great judgment, and went cross-court hard and flat off both wings. He served well, too, and took the sting out of his opponent’s booming missiles, block-defending when he could get a racket on the ball then working his way into the point, even if Anderson still managed to put 10 aces past him.

The South African, who lost to Murray at Wimbledon last year, said: “He’s a terrific player and has had such great success on all surfaces.”

When Murray and Troicki resumed their semi-final at 11am, the home favourite tidied up the first set from break-point in the seventh game, and had to hurdle a courtside box chasing down a drop shot in the second point of the first game in the second set, ending up about 10 feet from his opponent. It was one of a few obstacles on his way to victory, as Troicki offered stiff resistance all the way to the end.

If there was anything wrong with the Serb’s left shoulder after a heavy fall on Saturday night, his right one was in perfect working order as he consistently pounded down serves at around 130 miles an hour and invested his groundstrokes with serious muscle.

Murray has often said he is not a morning person but he was wide awake for Troicki. In the tie-break, he led 4-2 at the changeover, handed two points back on his serve and was grateful for Troicki’s final shot of the match after an extended rally, a smash from the baseline into the bottom of the net.

Both players got a standing ovation – and deserved it.

Related: Andy Murray v Kevin Anderson: Queen's Club final – as it happened

cards.title: Brazil 0-1 Australia / Simon's late goal knocks Brazil out of Women's World Cup
cards.rawTitle: Simon's late goal knocks Brazil out of Women's World Cup

item.title: Australia stun Brazil at Women's World Cup to make quarter-finals
item.trailText: The Matildas became the first ever senior Australian team to win a knockout game at a World Cup as they shocked Brazil
item.standFirst:
• Brazil 0-1 Matildas
  • Kyah Simon’s strike settles last 16 tie
  • First ever knockout win for Australia at a World Cup
  • Read Tom Lutz’s minute-by-minute
item.body:
The Matildas won through to the last eight of the Women’s World Cup in stunning style, eliminating Brazil. Kyah Simon’s 80th-minute goal was enough for Australia to cause the tournament’s biggest shock on Sunday in Moncton.

After an afternoon labouring in cold and damp conditions, two substitutes began and finished the decisive goal. Katrina Gorry’s fine pass released captain Lisa De Vanna on the right, whose shot was fumbled by Brazilian keeper Luciana into the path of Simon. Running with intent to the back post, Simon sidefooted the ball into the open net to give Australia their first tournament win over Brazil.

The win returns the Matildas to the last eight of the World Cup for the third straight time, but is the first knockout win for any Australian senior team after the expansion of the Women’s World Cup this year.

Australia will return to Edmonton for a quarter-final, which could be a rematch of the past two Asian Cup finals. Japan face the Netherlands for the right to play Australia, as the Matildas bid to reach the semi-finals for the first time.

A tactical first half in Moncton was devoid of clear chances. Sam Kerr’s sweet volley from Emily van Egmond’s corner on 10 minutes rippled the side-netting.

Full-backs Caitlin Foord and Steph Catley were lively attacking options, although the Matildas had their fair share of ragged moments. With the half-hour mark looming, Formiga dispossessed Van Egmond, and forced Matildas goalkeeper Lydia Williams to make a superb save from her swirling long-range strike.

After the half-time break, the rain came down and the match opened up. The Matildas had a major scare on 63 minutes when the unmarked Formiga headed into the post with the rain teeming down. De Vanna scurried the ball down the other end, teeing up van Egmond, who shot wide.

Brazil’s long-range strikes looked increasingly likely to beat Williams but the keeper held strong. By 72 minutes, both Gorry and Simon were on the field and, less than 10 minutes later, they made their impact.

After holding out a largely flat Brazilian attack, the Matildas had their slice of history and celebrated wildly on the final whistle.

cards.title: Austrian Grand Prix / Rosberg snatches victory from Hamilton at first corner
cards.rawTitle: Rosberg snatches victory from Hamilton at first corner

item.title: Nico Rosberg seizes Austrian F1 GP from Lewis Hamilton at first corner
item.trailText: Nico Rosberg overtook his Mercedes team-mate at the start and Lewis Hamilton’s fightback hopes were ended by a pit-lane penalty
item.standFirst:
• Mercedes pair complete one-two but in reverse order from grid
• Hamilton picks up time penalty for pit error and title-race lead is cut to 10
item.byline: Paul Weaver at the Red Bull Ring
item.body:
Nico Rosberg not only defeated Lewis Hamilton in the Austrian Grand Prix but also inflicted a level of damage on the world champion that was not so apparent in the German’s wins in Spain and Monaco. Rosberg was the stronger man here, coming from behind to beat his Mercedes team-mate with something to spare. Indeed, the German was better for most of the weekend, even in Saturday’s qualifying session when he was generally the more convincing despite Hamilton pipping him for pole.

Related: F1 Austrian Grand Prix 2015 – in pictures

This win has cut Hamilton’s lead to 10 points in the championship standings and, with the British Grand Prix at Silverstone coming up on 5 July, enlivens a narrative that had threatened to become a slightly tedious – the crowd on Sunday was a little more than half last season’s attendance in Austria.

Hamilton has been so dominant this season, at least on Saturdays, that he has won seven poles out of eight. But in terms of wins it is only 4-3 to him, with Sebastian Vettel taking the other race in Malaysia.

What Hamilton may find more perturbing is that there were extenuating circumstances for his previous two setbacks this year. In Spain, Rosberg started from pole and Hamilton from the dirty side of the track – he also suffered a messy pit stop and ultimately had three stops to the German’s two.

In Monaco, Hamilton dominated the entire weekend and, even though he was more culpable in his defeat than was immediately apparent, the decision to pull him in for an unnecessary tyre change was a major misjudgment by his team.

In Austria, Rosberg was simply superior, beating Hamilton as he did last year; the British driver will have to get his head around the challenges of the track built by the Red Bull team owner, Dietrich Mateschitz.

This was Rosberg’s 11th victory and he has never been more animated in triumph. There is every possibility that the title race will go to the final round in Abu Dhabi, just as it did last year. The only pity is that it is a purely internecine war.

Rosberg jumped Hamilton on the inside going into the first corner and then defended his advantage with ferocious determination. He said afterwards: “I had a good start and then good pace in the race – that is what I’m most happy about. I think I have found what I needed to find last year in terms of in the races and that’s what is really working out for me this year.”

A rather subdued Hamilton said: “I had a problem with the revs. I took my foot off the gas and the throttle was still on. It was not the best way to start the race but it is something we will work on to improve on my side of the garage.” Or Rosberg may just have caught him napping.

Before the pair came in for their solitary pit stop there was a five-lap period when Rosberg increased his lead from two seconds to four. Hamilton managed to reduce his disadvantage to 2.2sec but then, when the drivers pitted, Rosberg emerged the stronger once again. His stop was marginally the quicker (2.7 against 3.1) and the German built up his lead over the subsequent laps. When it emerged that Hamilton had crossed the white line at the pit exit, incurring a five-second penalty, Rosberg had in effect doubled his lead, from about five seconds to 10. But Rosberg would have won anyway. His only worry after that was some tyre vibrations in the closing stages.

The Mercedes motorsport chief, Toto Wolff, believes Rosberg exhibited the mental toughness in victory that will keep the championship race alive to the end. Asked how Rosberg manages to keep in touch with Hamilton, Wolff said: “I’ve been asked this before: ‘Is this the tipping point? Is he now going to be No2 [driver]?’ I kept repeating that he’s mentally very strong, and we’ve seen that today.

“Both of them are under pressure because they’re pushing each other so much. Nico was faultless. We saw from today it’s going to go down to the wire. The races we have seen have been characterised by tiny mistakes by both of them, or the team, and today we have seen great race pace and faultless execution by Nico. It was a great performance.”

Felipe Massa (Williams) and Sebastian Vettel (Ferrari) were next, followed by Valtteri Bottas (Williams) and Nico Hülkenberg (Force India).

The race got off to a dramatic start when there was a heavy collision between Fernando Alonso and Kimi Raikkonen – drivers usually extremely adept at keeping out of trouble. It is no small irony that earlier in the weekend Raikkonen had said that F1 should become “a little more dangerous”.

The Finn lost his rear end and Alonso, with nowhere to go, clattered into the back of him, putting both out of the race. They were also lucky to escape injury. It was an even more wretched weekend than usual for McLaren, with both of their cars out of the race by lap nine. Jenson Button, who like Alonso had been handed a 25-place grid penalty, was told to retire, and said: “When you have a 10sec stop-go penalty retiring on lap nine is never a bad thing. I chose to have the penalties this weekend rather than Silverstone. Hopefully we will have a clean weekend there.”

McLaren said: “A brief and very disappointing Austrian GP for the team. Time to get our heads down for testing and Silverstone.” But to add to their long list of troubles this season the damage to Alonso’s car – which had the upgrades ahead of Button’s for the race – is likely to compromise the final in-season testing session this week.

Final positions after race (71 laps)

1 Nico Rosberg (Ger) Mercedes 1hr 30min 16.930sec, 2 Lewis Hamilton (GB) Mercedes 1:30:25.730, 3 Felipe Massa (Br) Williams 1:30:34.503, 4 Sebastian Vettel (Ger) Ferrari 1:30:35.111, 5 Valtteri Bottas (Fin) Williams 1:31:10.534, 6 Nico Hülkenberg (Ger) Force India 1:31:21.005, 7 Pastor Maldonado (Ven) Lotus at 1 Lap, 8 Max Verstappen (Neth) Toro Rosso at 1 Lap, 9 Sergio Pérez (Mex) Force India at 1 Lap, 10 Daniel Ricciardo (Aus) Red Bull at 1 Lap, 11 Felipe Nasr (Br) Sauber at 1 Lap, 12 Daniil Kvyat (Rus) Red Bull at 1 Lap, 13 Marcus Ericsson (Swe) Sauber at 2 Laps, 14 Roberto Merhi (Sp) Manor at 3 Laps

cards.title: Football / Manchester United tell Real Madrid: if you want De Gea, we'll take Ramos
cards.rawTitle: Manchester United tell Real Madrid: if you want De Gea, we'll take Ramos

item.title: Manchester United tell Real Madrid: if you want De Gea, we’ll have Ramos
item.trailText: Manchester United have responded to Real Madrid’s bid for David De Gea by telling Spanish club they want to sign Sergio Ramos, the Guardian understands
item.standFirst:
• Sergio Ramos has €180m buyout clause and contract expires in July 2017
• Real negotiations over new deal with defender at standstill for some time
item.body:
Manchester United have responded to Real Madrid’s bid for David de Gea by telling the Spanish club they want to sign Sergio Ramos, the Guardian understands.

The 29-year-old central defender, who has 128 caps for Spain, has an official buyout clause of €180m (£128m) but his contract at the Bernabéu expires in July 2017 and United are believed to think they have a chance of signing Ramos without having to meet that figure.

Related: Football transfer rumours: Bastian Schweinsteiger to Manchester United?

Real Madrid have already had a n initial bid for De Gea turned down, believed to be in the region of €18m. Representatives then travelled to the UK for a meeting at which they requested United set a price for the goalkeeper. Madrid remain convinced they will eventually sign De Gea, who has one year left on his contract and wants to return to Spain, and anticipated a meeting that would be a formality. Instead they met a counter-bid: you want De Gea, we want Ramos.

The central defender has been at Real Madrid for 10 seasons since joining from Sevilla for €27m when he was still a teenager. He has played more than 400 games for Madrid and is the vice-captain but negotiations over a new contract have been at a standstill for some time. There have been significant hints of tension between the player and the club, encouraging United in their pursuit.

There has been interest from other clubs in Europe but none have communicated that directly to Madrid. Real deny having any offers at all. The Barcelona presidential candidate, Jordi Majo, claimed he had been indirectly offered Ramos two days ago. Real Madrid did not deny that story but the player’s camp did.

Ramos has two years left on the deal he signed in 2011, meaning Madrid’s hand may not yet be forced – certainly not to the extent that they believe United’s has been forced regarding De Gea.

It is unusual for Madrid to allow a player’s deal to enter into the final two years, though. According to calculations by the Spanish sports daily AS, 11 of the past 14 renewals undertaken by the president, Florentino Pérez, have been finalised before this stage.

sublinks.title: Football / West Ham confident £14m bid will lure Marseille’s Payet
sublinks.rawTitle: West Ham confident £14m bid will lure Marseille’s Payet

item.title: West Ham confident improved £14m bid will lure Marseille’s Dimitri Payet
item.trailText: West Ham United believe a second, £14m offer for the Marseille forward Dimitri Payet will force through the transfer of the France forward
item.standFirst:
• France forward to earn about £70,000 a week after move to Premier League
• Monaco’s Geoffrey Kondogbia on verge of joining Internazionale for £22m
item.body:
West Ham United are confident their improved offer for Dimitri Payet will force through the transfer of the Marseille forward. The player is understood to be keen to leave the Stade Vélodrome for a new challenge in the Premier League.

The club’s second offer amounts to around £14m for a player capped 15 times by France; an initial bid nearer £12m was rejected. The French club’s squad are undergoing something of a revamp after failing to qualify for next season’s Champions League; this failure prompted an automatic wage drop for players with Payet, 28, due to lose around £12,000 a week.

André Ayew and André-Pierre Gignac have left for Swansea and the Mexican club Tigres respectively under freedom of contract while the midfielder Giannelli Imbula is attracting interest from Italy. The Marseille coach, Marcelo Bielsa, had hoped Payet’s deal would be renegotiated but the temptation of a move to England – after Everton had previously shown interest – is believed to have turned his head.

A four-year contract has been offered with terms of around £70,000 a week. Payet can operate across the front line as well as in a No10 role and contributed the most assists in Ligue 1 last season. He would join the Spain Under-21 international Pedro Obiang, who moved from Sampdoria to Upton Park for £4.6m. The West Ham board is anxious to demonstrate ambition to the new manager, Slaven Bilic, before the club’s final season at the Boleyn Ground.

The need to reinforce is increased by West Ham competing in the Europa League, via the fair play rule. The draw for the first qualifying round takes place todayon Monday and their competitive season will begin on 2 July. Interest is retained in Barcelona’s Alex Song, who spent last season on loan at West Ham. The Catalan club are seeking around £5m for the midfielder, who was impressive over the first half of last season, though there is a reluctance to meet that fee.

Meanwhile the Monaco midfielder Geoffrey Kondogbiathe Monaco midfielder Geoffrey Kondogbia is set to disappoint clubs in the Premier League and sign a five-year contract at Internazionale after the clubs agreed a fee of £22m for the France international.

Both Arsenal, against whom he excelled in the first leg of their Champions League last-16 fixture last season, and Tottenham Hotspur have tracked the 22-year-old’s progress but the only firm bids were submitted by Inter and their rivals, Milan. Kondogbia, a France international, is due to undertake a medical on Monday today before completing his move.

cards.title: The Rumour Mill / Schweinsteiger to Manchester United?

item.title: Football transfer rumours: Bastian Schweinsteiger to Manchester United?
item.trailText: Carlos Bacca to Manchester United | Salomón Rondón to Liverpool? | Moussa Dembélé to Chelsea? | Joel Campbell to Benfica?
item.standFirst: Today’s piffle has found comedy value in the antics of squirrells
item.body:
Louis van Gaal has stopped thinking about saxophone solos for long enough to determine that his Manchester United squad is spineless. Yes, he wants more gumption from back to front. And he’s so impatient to fix it that he’ll don his scrubs, snap on his rubber gloves and perform a gory transplant – ripping out his side’s vertebrae, Mortal-Kombat-death-move-style, before shoving a new one in its stead.

Who will this spine consist of? Sergio Ramos, Bastian Schweinsteiger and Carlos Bacca, that’s who. It’s not a young spine. It’s almost 90 years old, but it’s seen the world and is probably strong enough not to bend to the will of Swansea City, and that’s what matters here.

Related: Manchester United tell Real Madrid: if you want De Gea, we’ll have Ramos

Schweinsteiger will check in for £7.5m worth of beans providing the midfielder puts his fingers in his ears and says “na, na, na, I’m not listening” as Franz Beckenbauer pleads with him to stay at Bayern Munich. Bacca will cost £20m once they’ve convinced the striker that there’s this thing called the Champions League, and although he’s very good at winning the Europa League it isn’t the be all and end all, and Liverpool really don’t care about it as much as his current club Sevilla seem to, so be a good boy and come to Manchester not Merseyside.

And then there’s Ramos, a man who was seemingly born just a yellow card away from suspension. Google his name. Hit the images button … and boom! That’s what £46.5m buys you these days. A player so easy to wind up you could put him in a room with a monk taking a vow of silence and he’d still find a way to be offended.

United won’t bother the Glazers for any cash, mind, the price is David De Gea to Real Madrid. It’s not a fair price in the Mill’s reckoning. But football’s mad isn’t it? Ramos’s value would drop quicker than that of a brand new Porsche driven straight into a wall off the forecourt.

But let’s move on shall we? What else? Liverpool have finally decided that giving £32.5m to Aston Villa for Christian Benteke is the equivalent of jumping out of the carriage into the roadside bushes and meekly handing their wares to the hiding highwayman. Instead they’ll sign Salomón Rondón, the 25-year-old Venezuala striker who plundered 20 goals in 36 matches for Zenit st Petersburg last season.

It says here that Chelsea want Tottenham’s Moussa Dembélé for £12m. Nope, The Mill can’t fathom that one either.

WILL SOMEBODY PLEASE JUST SIGN PAUL POGBA!

And relax.

Manchester City will shove £50m across the table for Raheem Sterling and see if Brendan Rodgers flinches. Meanwhile, they’ll somehow squeeze £17m out of Juventus for Stevan Jovetic, the tricky so and sos, and then sign midfielder Charles Aránguiz from Internacional for around £10m. “It makes me feel good … I would very much like to go,” trilled the Chile international.

Petr Cech and Arsenal have agreed how many notes will land in the goalkeeper’s bank account each week but José Mourinho would rather stick pins in his eyes than let the 33-year-old cosy up with Arsène Wenger so let’s leave that one there shall we?

Dimitar Berbatov has had a think about signing for Bournemouth. It wasn’t a very long think. He’s determined that Eddie Howe’s team moves around far too quickly for his liking. He’ll say farewell to Monaco and lounge around up front for Olympiakos instead.

Andrea Pirlo will put his feet up alongside Frank Lampard in New York City’s midfield.

Joel Campbell wants to feel like a footballer again and actually play football for a living. He’ll do so at Benfica if the club stumps up the £6m required to tempt Arsenal to undo the Costa Rica striker’s shackles and let him run free right out of the Emirates and straight into Arsenal tube station, where he’ll head for Heathrow. He may see Jackson Martínez trotting the other way if Wenger finally agrees to pay the £25m Porto want for the Colombia striker.

And finally, Alan Pardew and Ronald Koeman will do their best impressions of Oliver Reed and Alan Bates in Women in Love, as they wrestle over Charlie Austin. The winner’s club, be it Crystal Palace or Southampton, will have to send £15m the way of QPR. Oof!

cards.title: Sweden 0-1 England / Lingard’s late strike helps England U-21s sink Sweden
cards.rawTitle: Lingard’s late strike helps England U-21s sink Sweden

item.title: England Under-21 sink Sweden thanks to Jesse Lingard’s late volley
item.trailText: A superb goal from Jesse Lingard five minutes from time gave England a 1-0 win against Sweden in their second match at the European Under-21 Championship
item.standFirst:
• Sweden Under-21 0-1 England Under-21
• Lingard 85
item.body:
Jesse Lingard breathed life into England’s stuttering European Under-21 Championship campaign with a stunning late winner against Sweden that means Gareth Southgate’s side go into their final group game with their destiny in their own hands. This may have been a staccato performance, one that frustrated far more than it excited, but it means the side have broken a winless streak in these finals that had stretched back to 2009.

More importantly the semi-finals are back on the agenda. With the opening defeat against Portugal, coupled with the losses of Saido Berahino and John Stones to injury, threatening the equilibrium in the squad, much of Southgate’s preparation for this game had involved limiting the damage to the collective psyche. Perhaps this result can turn the tide.

“After the game the other night we had to stop the bleeding a little bit,” said Southgate. “We’d had hammer blows with the two injuries to outstanding players, then the manner of the goal we conceded and the defeat. So we had to do a lot of work making sure all of the noise around us didn’t affect us.

“We’ve made a step in the right direction. It’s in our hands. I think the momentum starts to swing with us a little bit now and that’s very important in football.”

Portugal’s goalless draw with Italy means the situation in Group B is a complex one. England do not need to beat Italy but failure to do so will leave them reliant on the other result.

They will have to improve for that fixture. Tactical tinkering and personnel changes for Sweden had been long-planned and the onus was on Will Hughes and Alex Pritchard, coming into the side in place of James Ward-Prowse and Lingard, to provide the attacking impetus that flickered only sporadically against Portugal. Neither would be on the pitch after an hour, with Danny Ings introduced for Hughes at half-time and Pritchard hobbling off to be replaced by the eventual goalscorer.

Perhaps more than anything the absence of Stones, who had been earmarked as the defensive launchpad for England’s passing game, has been felt most keenly in the two games to date. Concussion protocols allow him to return for the final game – a rather less understandable protocol, this time from Uefa, meant the squad had to travel the 100 yards or so from hotel to Andruv Stadium on the team coach.

The Everton defender’s likely return against the Italians should add some much-needed drive. But the stodgy performance was not all England’s making – Sweden’s win over Italy in their opening game afforded Hakan Ericson’s side the luxury of conservatism. There was a very different shape to this game from that in the Portugal tie, with England dominating the ball – they enjoyed 62% of possession – and trying to conjure space between their opponents’ two banks of four.

It was a struggle. Almost half an hour had passed before England truly threatened the Sweden goal. Nathan Redmond fed Carl Jenkinson on the right and his low cross was nodded just wide by a diving Harry Kane. That chance began England’s best period of the first 45 minutes, with Hughes denied brilliantly by Filip Helander’s goal-saving tackle after Pritchard’s clever delayed pull-back and Pritchard himself denied by sheer weight of numbers after a ferreting run into the box.

Those chances, though, were islands of excitement in an ocean of frustration. Before half-time Jack Butland was only twice called into action, first to gather John Guidetti’s low shot, then to claim Isaac Kiese Thelin’s header, and neither save was taxing.

Nor was Butland unduly taxed in the second half and, for far longer than would have been comfortable for Southgate, neither was Patrik Carlgren in the Sweden goal. A clear pattern was set – England dominated the ball but again struggled to make the best use of it. It was by no means abject but nor was there much food for thought for the watching Roy Hodgson as he ponders plans for the remainder of the Euro 2016 qualifying campaign. With five minutes go there was that creeping familiar sense that England and tournaments simply do not mix.

Then Lingard, introduced early in the second half for the injured Pritchard – “It didn’t look very good,” was Southgate’s immediate prognosis and the midfielder left the stadium on crutches – produced a moment of brilliance. Carlgren flapped a Luke Garbutt corner to the edge of the box and the Manchester United midfielder chested it down before sending a fizzing volley back past the Sweden goalkeeper.

“We had to show a lot of character and resilience because we knew how difficult it would be to break Sweden down,” said Southgate. “We felt we could wear them down the longer the game went on. We had to remain positive right to the end. We dominated possession.

“I think our tempo at times could have been a bit quicker but maybe that was the burden of young players feeling the need to win the game.”

That burden will still be there when the side face Italy in the same stadium on Wednesday but at least the dam has been broken.

sublinks.title: Italy 0-0 Portugal / Stalemate leaves England with all to play for
sublinks.rawTitle: Stalemate leaves England with all to play for

item.title: Italy and Portugal stalemate means England U21s have all to play for
item.trailText: Italy and Portugal drew 0-0 in Group B of the European Under-21 Championship to leave England with a good chance of qualifying for the semi-finals
item.standFirst: • European Under-21 Championship: Italy 0-0 Portugal
item.body:
Italy’s qualification hopes were left in the balance after a spirited 0-0 draw against Portugal in Uherske Hradiste. Both sides can still progress from Group B but Italy must now defeat England to make the semi-finals.

Italy made five changes after the defeat to Sweden, the coach, Luigi Di Biagio, dropping his captain, Matteo Bianchetti, and the Azzurrini were much improved in their new shape, with a three-man midfield.

The Portugal goalkeeper José Sá was busy early on, palming over Marco Benassi’s shot in the first 15 seconds. Domenico Berardi led the attack, outshining his opposite number Bernardo Silva in the first half. He twice created chance for Andrea Belotti. The first, after six minutes, brought a fine low save from the feet of José Sá and the second intervention by the Portugal No1 left Belotti kicking the post in frustration close to the midway point in the half.

Portugal’s first chance came after 26 minutes when Sérgio Oliveira played the ball back for João Mário, only for the forward to shoot wide.

Italy again pushed at the start of the second half, Belotti diving in bravely ahead of José Sá to flick Cristiano Biraghi’s left-wing cross against the bar. Their best chance came in the dying seconds of added time, when the Italy left-back Biraghi was clean through but could not control the ball to take advantage, leaving the game all square.
